column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0067]FIG. 8b differs from FIG. 8a in that it builds into the circuit an easy and inexpensive means of protecting the LEDs from excessive current flow and the runaway that results from high temperatures.
#Text=In this circuit a resistor with a positive resistance rate of change with temperature, R2 807 is placed in series with a fixed resistor.
#Text=Resistor R2 is physically located on the circuit board so as to be placed in the thermal pathway of heat emanating from the LEDs 805.
#Text=Therefore, when the temperature of the LEDs 805 increases, the resistance of R2 807 also increases, and its resistance is added to that of R1 806.
#Text=Since the voltage drop across these combined resistances appears on the feedback pin FB of IC1 801, the increased voltage is interpreted as a request for decreased current.
#Text=Hence, the natural tendency of the LEDs 805 to draw more current that would ordinarily lead to the failure of the part is averted by introducing a self-limiting control function.

#Text=[0068]This circuit has the advantage of being very efficient and compact and having built into it a temperature regulation that allows the resulting system to automatically adapt to the thermal environment in which it is placed.
#Text=Because of these attributes, it can, for example be put into a miniature lamp base of the kind used for flashlights (PR type flange base).
#Text=[0069]However, the remaining limitation of the circuit is that it can only boost voltage from a lower value to a higher value required by the LED load.

#Text=Therefore, in situations where only one LED is required, but a higher input voltage is all that is available, the excess voltage will appear across the LED even if the circuits in FIG. 8 are used.
#Text=This will cause an excessive current to be drawn, leading to premature failure of the LED and premature draining of the battery.

#Text=To solve this problem we require a circuit that is still compact enough to fit into a bulb or bulb base, and that is capable of either raising or lowering the output voltage above or below the voltage of the incoming battery or other dc supply in order to maintain the desired current through the LED load.

#Text=Hence this circuit would either boost the voltage if the input voltage were lower than required by the LED or reduce the voltage if it were higher than that required to sustain the necessary constant current through the LED.
#Text=It is understood that LED here may refer to one or more LEDs in a series, parallel or series/parallel circuit.
#Text=Furthermore, because of the deleterious effects of temperature, this circuit must have the ability to regulate the current through the LED depending on the ambient temperature.
#Text=The ambient temperature may be determined by the environment as well as heat dissipated by the circuit and the LED.
#Text=[0070]Such a circuit is disclosed in FIG. 9.
#Text=This circuit utilizes a so-called Cuk converter that is ordinarily used as an inverting switching voltage regulator.
#Text=Such a device inverts the polarity of the source voltage and regulates the output voltage depending on the values of a resistor bridge.

#Text=In this invention, the inverter circuit has been altered in a unique fashion so that it acts to boost the voltage output or buck the voltage input in order to maintain a constant current through the load represented by one or more LEDs 905.
#Text=The circuit incorporates an integrated circuit IC1 901 such as the National Semiconductor LM2611 Cuk Converter or equivalent.
#Text=In this circuit, IC1's internal transistor is closed during the first cycle charging the inductor L1 902 from the battery source indicated as Vbat.
#Text=At the same time the capacitor C2 904 charges inductor L2 903, while the output current to the LEDs 905 is supplied by inductor L2 903.
#Text=In the next cycle the IC1 901 changes state to permit the inductor L1 902 to charge capacitor C2 904 and L2 903 to discharge through the LEDs 905.
#Text=The control of the charging power and current through the load is performed by the resistor network consisting of R2 906a and R3 907a.
#Text=The overall value of these resistors together with the current passing through the LEDs 905 from ground, sets a voltage that appears on the feedback pin (FB) of IC1 901.
#Text=Resistor 907a has a positive temperature coefficient so that its resistance increases with temperature.

#Text=[0071]Because of thermal effects such as heat dissipation by the LEDs, heat produced by the IC1 or other circuit components and the ambient environmental conditions, the current must also be altered to accommodate these changes.
#Text=This is affected by a temperature dependent resistor R3.
#Text=In FIG. 9a, resistor R3 907a has a positive temperature coefficient in which the resistance increases with temperature.
#Text=The additive effect of the series circuit with R2 906a means that as temperature rises, the overall resistance of the combination does also, leading to an increase in voltage drop.
#Text=This in turn causes IC1 to decrease the output current to the LEDs 905.
#Text=In FIG. 9b the resistor network is comprised of resistors in parallel and series.
#Text=In this instance, resistors R2 and R4 906b, 908 are fixed and resistor R3 907b is temperature dependent with a positive temperature coefficient.
#Text=The use of a parallel arrangement allows a greater freedom of choice of temperature dependence than a simple series arrangement.
